dt: {bc}to constrain or strain to tension by curving

dt.t: {wi}bend{/wi} a bow

dt: {bc}to turn or force from straight or even to curved or angular

dt.t: {wi}bend{/wi} a pipe
Her bicycle's back wheel got {it}bent{/it} in the crash.

dt: {bc}to force back to an original straight or even condition

dt.t: {wi}bend{/wi} the wire flat
{wi}bend{/wi} a sail to its yard

dt: {bc}to cause to turn from a straight course {bc}{sx|deflect||}

dt.t: {wi}bend{/wi} a ray of light with a mirror
… {wi}bends{/wi} his rapid steps in the direction of the headquarters …
{wi}bending{/wi} their minds to the Buddhist concept of eternity
{wi}bend{/wi} the rules
{it}bent{/it} himself to the task
refusing to be {it}bent{/it}

dt: {bc}to curve out of a straight line or position

dt.t: The road {wi}bends{/wi} to the left.
tree limbs {wi}bending{/wi} under the weight of the snow
{it}bent{/it} down to pick up a piece of paper
{it}bending{/it} double with pain

dt: {bc}to incline the body in token of submission

dt.t: {wi}bend{/wi} to the queen
{wi}bending{/wi} to their work
She {wi}bends{/wi} to the Left politically.
refusing to {wi}bend{/wi} under pressure to change
{wi}bending{/wi} to the will of wealthy supporters
had to {it}bend over backward{/it} to get these tickets

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}bendan{/it}; akin to Old English {it}bend{/it} fetter {ma}{mat|band|}{/ma}
shortdef: to constrain or strain to tension by curving
to turn or force from straight or even to curved or angular
to force from a proper shape

dt.t: doing knee {wi}bends{/wi}
the graceful {wi}bends{/wi} of Gothic windows

dt: {bc}a curved part of a path (as of a stream or road)

dt.t: Their house is down the road, just past the {wi}bend{/wi}.

ins.spl: plural in form but singular or plural in construction

dt: {bc}intense joint pain occurring as a common manifestation of decompression sickness

dt.t: a case of {wi}the bends{/wi}
appears to have gone {it}around the bend{/it}

shortdef: the act or process of bending : the state of being bent
something that is bent: such as
a curved part of a path (as of a stream or road)

dt: {bc}a diagonal band that runs from the {d_link|dexter|dexter} chief {dx_def}see {dxt|chief:3||1}{/dx_def} to the {d_link|sinister|sinister} base {dx_def}see {dxt|base:1||8}{/dx_def} on a heraldic shield {dx}compare {dxt|bend sinister||}{/dx}

et: Middle English, band, from Old English {it}bend{/it} fetter {ma}{mat|band|}{/ma}
dt: {bc}a knot by which one rope is fastened to another or to some object

et: Middle English, from Middle French {it}bende{/it}, of Germanic origin; akin to Old High German {it}binta, bant{/it} band {ma}{mat|band|}{/ma}
shortdef: a diagonal band that runs from the dexter chief to the sinister base on a heraldic shield
a knot by which one rope is fastened to another or to some object

dt: city on the Deschutes River in central Oregon {it}population{/it} 76,639

shortdef: city on the Deschutes River in central Oregon population 76,639

dt: {bc}a diagonal band that runs from the sinister chief to the dexter base on a heraldic shield

shortdef: a diagonal band that runs from the sinister chief to the dexter base on a heraldic shield

dt: {bc}to not be strict or exact about following a rule

dt.t: She's not really quite old enough to be admitted as a member, but she's very close, so I think we can {it}bend the rule(s){/it} a little in her case and let her in now.

shortdef: to not be strict or exact about following a rule

dt.t: I held on tight as my fishing rod {it}bent double{/it}.
He {it}bent double{/it} in pain.

dt: {bc}to talk to someone for a long time

dt.t: He didn't really care about me, he just wanted to {it}bend my ear{/it} about his own problems.

shortdef: to talk to someone for a long time

dt: {bc}to change facts in a dishonest way in order to deceive people

dt.t: a journalist who has been accused of {it}bending the facts{/it} in order to gain support for his political agenda

shortdef: to change facts in a dishonest way in order to deceive people

dt: {bc}to say something that is not true or that misleads people but that is usually not regarded as a serious or harmful lie

dt.t: When he tells people he's from Manhattan he's {it}bending the truth{/it} a little since he really grew up in Brooklyn.

shortdef: to say something that is not true or that misleads people but that is usually not regarded as a serious or harmful lie
